hypothesis.name: Optimal Mid-Tilt Configuration
hypothesis.rationale: A moderate tilt angle (around 30°) is often effective for maximizing solar gain throughout the day, especially in temperate climates.

hypothesis.name: High Capacity with Low Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: A low tilt angle (10°) combined with high system capacity (15 kW) may capture more sunlight during peak hours, especially in regions with high solar insolation.

hypothesis.name: East-Facing Setup
hypothesis.rationale: An azimuth angle of 90° (east-facing) with a higher tilt (45°) can be beneficial for capturing morning sunlight, particularly in summer months.

hypothesis.name: West-Facing High Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: A west-facing azimuth (270°) with a tilt of 60° may optimize energy capture in the afternoon, which is crucial for maximizing daily output.

hypothesis.name: Balanced Configuration
hypothesis.rationale: A balanced approach with a tilt of 25° and azimuth of 180° can provide a good compromise for energy capture throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt and Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: Higher tilt angles (around 66°) with maximum system capacity (20 kW) have shown to maximize energy output.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt with High Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: A moderate tilt (around 50°) with high system capacity (20 kW) can balance energy capture throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: Exploring East-Facing High Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: An east-facing azimuth (90°) with a tilt of 70° may capture morning sunlight effectively, especially with high capacity.

hypothesis.name: West-Facing Configuration
hypothesis.rationale: A west-facing azimuth (270°) with a tilt of 65° could optimize afternoon energy capture, complementing the morning configurations.

hypothesis.name: Balanced Configuration
hypothesis.rationale: A balanced approach with a tilt of 40° and azimuth of 180° can provide consistent energy capture throughout the day.
